name: Lovász conjecture
rephrased: Every finite, connected graph where all vertices are equivalent (vertex-transitive) contains a path that visits every vertex exactly once (a Hamiltonian path).
implication_form: If a graph is finite, connected, and vertex-transitive, then it has a Hamiltonian path.
explained: The Lovász conjecture (1969), now standardly stated, asserts that every finite, connected graph that is vertex-transitive contains a Hamiltonian path. A Hamiltonian path visits each vertex exactly once. Although László Lovász originally posed the problem in the opposite form, the current formulation—that vertex-transitive graphs possess Hamiltonian paths—has become widely accepted and studied.
